metadata.title: Akútna bolesť na hrudníku - Predný STEMI
learning_objectives: Zvládnuť komplikáciu zástavy srdca pri VF/VT
Aplikovať usmernenia pre kyslíkovú terapiu založené na dôkazoch

changelog.v2.0_final_enhanced: Pridaný kognitívny tréning druhej úrovne (interaktívne výzvy, kritické rozhodovacie body s úplnými rubrikami). Rozšírený zoznam liekov na 30+ liekov organizovaných podľa úrovne poškodenia. Pridané sekcie treatment_responses, aar_teaching_points a simulation_config. Vylepšená farmakokinetika pre všetky lieky. Úplná parita so štruktúrou scenára Astma.

dispatch_info.additional_info: Pacient sa sťažuje na silnú zvieravú bolesť na hrudníku približne 25 minút. Manželka hlási, že sa silno potí, vyzerá veľmi bledo a zle. Bolesť začala pri sledovaní televízie, myslel si, že je to zlé trávenie, ale nezlepšuje sa to. Pacient vyzerá byť v tiesni a vystrašený.

scene_description.bystanders: Prítomná manželka, veľmi úzkostlivá, pozná pacientovu anamnézu

patient_profile.name: Miroslav
patient_profile.personality: Úzkostlivý, snaží sa zľahčovať symptómy, bojí sa, že má infarkt

initial.student_sees: Prichádzate k mužovi v strednom veku, ktorý sedí predklonený v kresle a pravou rukou si zviera stred hrudníka. Je viditeľne bledý, na čele mu perlí pot a presakuje mu cez košeľu. Neustále sa mračí od bolesti a jeho dýchanie sa zdá byť namáhavé. Keď vstúpite, pozerá na vás s očividným strachom v očiach. Jeho manželka stojí neďaleko a úzkostlivo si žmolí ruky.
initial.appearance: Bledý, spotený, úzkostlivý, sedí predklonený, zviera si hrudník, mračí sa od bolesti, zjavná bolesť v ľavej ruke
initial.clinical_note: Klasická prezentácia STEMI: zvieravá substernálna bolesť na hrudníku >20 minút, vyžarovanie do ľavej ruky a sánky, potenie, žiadna úľava v pokoji. Vysoké podozrenie na predný IM vzhľadom na závažnú prezentáciu. Vyžaduje OKAMŽITÉ 12-zvodové EKG do 4 minút, okamžite aspirín a aktiváciu STEMI siete. Toto je časovo kritické - každá minúta oneskoruje definitívnu liečbu. SpO2 96% znamená NEPODÁVAŤ kyslík podľa usmernení ERC 2021.

improving.student_sees: Pacient vyzerá teraz viditeľne pohodlnejšie. Jeho dýchanie sa uvoľnilo, a hoci je stále bledý, už sa neustále nemračí. 'Bolesť je... stále tam, ale je to lepšie,' hovorí, jeho hlas je menej napätý. 'Možno tak 5 z 10 teraz namiesto 9. Môžem trochu ľahšie dýchať.' Potenie sa znížilo, hoci jeho košeľa je stále vlhká. Jeho manželka vyzerá o niečo menej panicky. Je schopný hovoriť v celých vetách bez prerušenia na nádych.
improving.appearance: Stále bledý, ale menej spotený, bolesť viditeľne znížená, hovorí v celých vetách, menej úzkostlivý, dýcha ľahšie
improving.clinical_note: Pacient reaguje na antianginóznu liečbu (aspirín ± nitráty). Zníženie bolesti je priaznivé, ale NEZNAMENÁ to, že sa zabránilo IM - poškodenie buniek pokračuje. EKG ukáže ST elevácie. Pokračujte v urgentnom transporte do PCI centra. Čas od nástupu symptómov po PCI je kritický - cieľ <120 minút od diagnózy. Toto zlepšenie je len symptomatické; záchrana myokardu vyžaduje urgentnú PCI.

deteriorating.student_sees: Pacient náhle vyzerá horšie. Jeho bolesť, ktorá sa zlepšila, sa opäť zintenzívňuje. 'Je to... je to horšie,' lapá po dychu, tvár má skrivenú. 'Tlak... nemôžem... dýchať...' Jeho koža zosivela s modrastým nádychom okolo pier. Dýcha rýchlo a plytko, bojuje o každý nádych. Zrazu si prudko zviera hrudník a oči sa mu prevrátia. Jeho manželka kričí. Vidíte, ako začína strácať vedomie, jeho telo ochabuje v kresle.
deteriorating.appearance: Závažná tieseň, popolavý/cyanotický, rýchle plytké dýchanie, zviera si hrudník, stráca vedomie, predzástavový stav
deteriorating.clinical_note: KRITICKÉ: Pacient rozvíja kardiogénny šok alebo malígnu arytmiu (hroziaca VF/VT). Toto je predný STEMI s rozsiahlym poškodením myokardu spôsobujúcim buď zlyhanie pumpy alebo elektrickú nestabilitu. Okamžitá príprava na zástavu srdca - pripojte defibrilátor TERAZ, pripravte sa na KPR. Ak to ešte nebolo urobené, tento pacient potrebuje URGENTNÝ transport s prednemocničným oznámením. Vysoké riziko náhlej srdcovej smrti. Predný IM postihujúci veľké teritórium myokardu.

critical.student_sees: Pacient nereaguje. Je zosunutý v kresle, nedýcha normálne - len občasné lapavé dychy. Jeho manželka hystericky plače. Keď kontrolujete pulz, na karotíde ho nenájdete. Monitor ukazuje komorovú fibriláciu - chaotický, mihotavý rytmus. Toto je náhla zástava srdca z jeho infarktu. Musíte okamžite začať KPR a pripraviť sa na výboj.
critical.appearance: Nereagujúci, bez pulzu, agonálne alebo neprítomné dýchanie, VF na monitore, zástava srdca
critical.clinical_note: ZÁSTAVA SRDCA sekundárne pri prednom STEMI. VF/bezpulzová VT je prezentujúci rytmus v ~80% náhlych srdcových smrtí z IM. Vyžaduje okamžitú KPR a defibriláciu podľa usmernení ERC 2021. Po ROSC pacient potrebuje urgentnú PCI na koronárnu reperfúziu - toto je definitívna liečba. Prognóza je neistá, ale zachrániteľná, ak sa ROSC dosiahne rýchlo a vykoná sa PCI. Pokračujte v podávaní aspirínu aj pri zástave (možno podať cez NG sondu, ak je intubovaný). Táto zástava je z ischemickej VF, vysoko šokovateľná.

initial_to_improving.student_actions_needed: Podaný aspirín + vykonané EKG + rozpoznaný STEMI
initial_to_improving.teaching_note: Včasné podanie aspirínu a zhotovenie EKG sú kritické. Nitráty pomáhajú symptómom, ale nezabránia IM - definitívna liečba je PCI. NEPODÁVAJTE kyslík, ak je SpO2 ≥90%.

initial_to_deteriorating.description: Bez antiagregačnej liečby a rýchlej diagnózy sa IM rozširuje, čo spôsobuje kardiogénny šok alebo malígnu arytmiu

deteriorating_to_critical.description: Rozsiahly IM vedie k zástave pri VF - šokovateľná zástava srdca

improving_to_stable.description: Pacient stabilizovaný primeranou liečbou, na ceste do PCI centra

airway.deteriorating: V ohrození, pacient sa stáva menej responzívnym
airway.critical: Nereagujúci, vyžaduje základné manévre na uvoľnenie dýchacích ciest, pripraviť na intubáciu

breathing.initial: Mierne zvýšená DF 22/min, čisté dýchacie zvuky bilaterálne, žiadne vrapky ani piskoty, SpO2 96% na izbovom vzduchu
breathing.deteriorating: DF 28/min, namáhavé, možný rozvoj pľúcneho edému pri zlyhaní ĽK, vrapky na bázach, SpO2 92%
breathing.critical: Agonálne dýchanie alebo apnoe, vyžaduje ventilačnú podporu

circulation.initial: SF 98/min pravidelná, TK 145/88, silné radiálne pulzy bilaterálne, CRT <2s, koža bledá a spotená
circulation.improving: SF 92/min, TK 138/84, pulzy silné, menej spotený
circulation.deteriorating: SF 118/min alebo bradykardický pri rozvoji srdcového bloku, TK 110/70 alebo klesajúci, pulzy slabé, koža studená a vlhká, známky šoku
circulation.critical: Bez pulzu, VF/VT na monitore, zástava srdca

disability.initial: GCS 15 (O4 V5 M6), pri vedomí a úzkostlivý, zrenice izokorické, reagujúce na svetlo

exposure.initial: Bez traumy, bez vyrážok, spotený, skontrolovať náplasti s liekmi (odstrániť všetky nitrátové náplasti pred podaním nitrátov)

symptoms.chief_complaint: Zvieravá substernálna bolesť na hrudníku, 'slon na hrudi'
symptoms.wife_reports: Nikdy predtým takúto bolesť nemal. Stále hovoril, že je to zlé trávenie, ale vedela som, že niečo nie je v poriadku.

current: Aspirín 100mg denne - KRITICKÉ: 'Užívam ho, ale pred 2 týždňami som prestal, lebo mi došiel'
medications.recent_use: Dnes ráno si vzal liek na tlak
medications.viagra_cialis_check: TREBA SA OPÝTAŤ: 'Užili ste Viagru, Cialis alebo podobné lieky za posledných 48 hodín?' - Pacient popiera

major_conditions: Bývalý fajčiar - prestal pred 5 rokmi (30 balíčkorokov)
past_medical_history.cardiac_history: Žiadny predchádzajúci IM, žiadne predchádzajúce epizódy bolesti na hrudníku
past_medical_history.last_physical: Pred 6 mesiacmi, lekár povedal 'dávajte si pozor na cholesterol'

events.precipitating: Žiadna námaha, sedel pri sledovaní televízie, keď bolesť začala
events.progression: Začala náhle, zhoršila sa počas prvých 5 minút, odvtedy zostala silná 9/10
events.family_context: Manželka veľmi znepokojená, otec zomrel na infarkt vo veku 62 rokov

focused_exam.cardiovascular: Srdcové ozvy normálne S1 S2, žiadne šelesty počuteľné na začiatku (môžu sa vyvinúť pri MR z dysfunkcie papilárneho svalu), JVP na začiatku normálne (môže stúpať pri postihnutí PK), žiadny periférny edém, oba radiálne pulzy prítomné a rovnaké
focused_exam.respiratory: Čisté dýchacie zvuky bilaterálne na začiatku, žiadne vrapky (môžu sa vyvinúť neskôr pri zlyhaní ĽK)
focused_exam.neurological: Pri vedomí, orientovaný x3, hlavové nervy hrubo intaktné, pohybuje všetkými končatinami
focused_exam.other: Brucho mäkké, nebolestivé, bez défense alebo rebound. Žiadne známky disekcie aorty (rovnaké pulzy, žiadny rozdiel TK na rukách)

assessment_findings.chief_complaint_detail: Pacient opisuje: 'Cítim sa, akoby mi na hrudi sedel slon. Ten tlak je hrozný. Ide mi to do ľavej ruky, do sánky. Je mi na vracanie. Potím sa ako blázon, aj keď mi je zima. Ja... myslím, že by to mohol byť infarkt. Môj otec na jeden zomrel.'

ecg_findings.note: Integrácia EKG pre vizuálne zobrazenie - pre MVP, opíšte nálezy študentovi
findings: ST elevácia 3-4mm vo zvodoch V1, V2, V3, V4 (predná stena)
ST elevácia 2mm vo zvodoch I a aVL (vysoké laterálne postihnutie)
Recipročné ST depresie vo zvodoch II, III, aVF (spodné zvody)
Vysoké špicaté T vlny v predných zvodoch (hyperakútne T vlny)
Zatiaľ žiadne Q vlny (akútny IM, Q vlny sa vyvíjajú neskôr)
ecg_findings.interpretation: AKÚTNY PREDNÝ STEMI - oklúzia RIA (ramus interventricularis anterior)
ecg_findings.teaching_point: Predný STEMI s vysokým laterálnym rozšírením - veľká oblasť myokardu v ohrození. RIA zásobuje prednú stenu, septum a hrot - toto je VEĽKÝ IM. Recipročné zmeny (ST depresie v spodných zvodoch) potvrdzujú, že toto NIE JE perikarditída alebo iné napodobeniny STEMI. Hyperakútne T vlny naznačujú veľmi skorý IM (<1 hodina). Tento pacient potrebuje urgentnú PCI TERAZ. Každá minúta oneskorenia zvyšuje mortalitu a znižuje pravdepodobnosť úplného zotavenia.

anopyrin_aspirin.indication: Akútny koronárny syndróm, STEMI, NSTEMI, nestabilná angína, TIA/CMP, horúčka, bolesť
anopyrin_aspirin.mechanism: Ireverzibilne inhibuje cyklooxygenázu (COX-1) doštičiek, čím zabraňuje syntéze tromboxánu A2 a tým inhibuje agregáciu doštičiek. Účinok trvá po celú dobu života doštičky (~7-10 dní). Pri AKS zabraňuje propagácii trombu v mieste ruptúry plaku.

dosing.acs_loading_rationale: Nasycovacia dávka dosiahne terapeutický antiagregačný účinok za 14 minút pri rozžuvaní vs 30 minút pri prehltnutí
dosing.maintenance: 100mg denne (pacient už môže byť na tejto liečbe)
dosing.pediatric: Zvyčajne sa nepoužíva pri pediatrickom AKS
dosing.administration: MUSÍ SA ROZŽUŤ pre rýchlu absorpciu pri AKS

pharmacokinetics.note: Antiagregačný účinok trvá po celú dobu života doštičky napriek krátkemu polčasu

side_effects: Zriedkavé: bronchospazmus u astmatikov citlivých na aspirín
warnings: MUSÍTE podať nasycovaciu dávku 200mg pri AKS, aj keď pacient užíva denný aspirín
MUSÍ sa rozžuť, nie prehltnúť, pre rýchlejší účinok
Opýtajte sa na alergiu na aspirín pred podaním
V tomto scenári: pacient užíva aspirín 100mg doma, ale prestal pred 2 týždňami - stále podajte 200mg nasycovaciu dávku

vital_changes.note: Žiadne okamžité zmeny vitálnych funkcií, ale antiagregačný účinok začína do 14 minút

scenario_specific_response.patient_says: Pacient rozžuje tabletu, mračí sa na horkú chuť. 'To chutí hrozne... ale ak to pomôže...' Žiadna okamžitá úľava od bolesti.
scenario_specific_response.clinical_effect: Aspirín znižuje mortalitu pri STEMI o 23%. Zabraňuje propagácii trombu v mieste ruptúry koronárneho plaku. Účinok je okamžitý na doštičky, ale pacient nepocíti subjektívne zlepšenie - toto je ochrana na bunkovej úrovni. Nevyhnutná liečba prvej línie. Podajte PRED dokončením úplného vyšetrenia - je to tak kritické.
scenario_specific_response.timing_critical: Musí sa podať do 3 minút od príchodu pre plný počet bodov. Každá minúta oneskorenia zvyšuje mortalitu.
scenario_specific_response.teaching_point: Aspirín je NAJdôležitejší prednemocničný liek pri STEMI - 23% zníženie mortality. Podajte ho OKAMŽITE po rozpoznaní pravdepodobného AKS, nečakajte na potvrdenie EKG. Nasycovacia dávka je 200mg rozžuvaná (aj keď pacient užíva denný aspirín doma). Žuvanie je kritické - dosahuje terapeutické hladiny za 14 minút vs 30 minút pri prehltnutí. Tento jeden jednoduchý zásah zachraňuje viac životov ako čokoľvek iné, čo robíme v prednemocničnej starostlivosti okrem defibrilácie.

nitromin_nitroglycerin.indication: Angina pectoris, akútny koronárny syndróm (úľava od symptómov), hypertenzná kríza, akútny pľúcny edém
nitromin_nitroglycerin.mechanism: Donor oxidu dusnatého → relaxácia hladkého svalstva ciev → venodilatácia (↓preload) > arteriálna dilatácia (↓afterload). Pri AKS: znižuje spotrebu kyslíka myokardom, môže zlepšiť kolaterálny koronárny prietok. NEZABRAŇUJE IM ani neznižuje mortalitu - čisto symptomatický.

dosing.repeat: Možno opakovať každých 5 minút, maximálne 3 dávky
dosing.administration: Pacient by mal sedieť alebo ležať (riziko synkopy z hypotenzie)

warnings: VŽDY skontrolujte TK pred podaním - nepodávajte, ak je sTK <90
VŽDY sa pýtajte na Viagru/Cialis - kombinácia spôsobuje závažnú hypotenziu a smrť
Pri PREDNOM IM (tento pacient): nitráty sú BEZPEČNÉ, ak to TK dovoľuje
Pri SPODNOM IM s postihnutím PK: nitráty sú KONTRAINDIKOVANÉ
Pacient by mal pred podaním sedieť/ležať
Nechajte pacienta odstrániť všetky nitrátové náplasti pred podaním ďalších nitrátov

scenario_specific_response.patient_says: 'Ó... to trochu pomáha. Tlak je menší. Ale moja hlava... teraz ma bolí hlava.' Pacient vyzerá pohodlnejšie, ale nie bez bolesti.
scenario_specific_response.clinical_effect: Symptomatická úľava prostredníctvom zníženia preloadu. Bolesť klesá z 9→6/10. Bolesť hlavy je očakávaný vedľajší účinok. TK klesá o 15-20mmHg (prijateľné). NEZABRAŇUJE IM ani neznižuje mortalitu - len manažment symptómov. Definitívna liečba je PCI. Nitráty sú podporná starostlivosť.
scenario_specific_response.teaching_point: Nitráty sú na úľavu od SYMPTÓMOV pri AKS, nie na zníženie mortality. Znižujú preload → znižujú spotrebu kyslíka myokardom → menej bolesti na hrudníku. KRITICKÁ BEZPEČNOSŤ: (1) Najprv skontrolujte TK (nepodávajte, ak je systolický <90), (2) Opýtajte sa na Viagru/Cialis (kontraindikované do 24-48h), (3) Predný IM (tento pacient) = nitráty BEZPEČNÉ. Spodný IM + postihnutie PK = nitráty NEBEZPEČNÉ (spôsobujú závažnú hypotenziu). Bolesť hlavy je očakávaná - nitroglycerín vazodilatuje aj mozgové cievy. Pacient si môže neskôr vziať paracetamol na bolesť hlavy.

tramal_morphine.indication: Silná bolesť, akútny koronárny syndróm (refraktérna bolesť na hrudníku), akútny pľúcny edém (znižuje preload a úzkosť)
tramal_morphine.mechanism: Agonista mü-opioidných receptorov → analgézia, anxiolýza, venodilatácia (znižuje preload), útlm dýchania pri vysokých dávkach

dosing.acs_adult: 2-4mg IV pomaly, opakovať každých 5-10 minút PRN pri refraktérnej bolesti
dosing.administration: Podávajte pomaly IV počas 2-3 minút, aby sa predišlo útlmu dýchania

warnings: Usmernenia ACC/AHA 2025: morfín NIE JE rutinný pri AKS
Morfín oneskoruje absorpciu perorálnych antiagregačných liekov (tikagrelor, prasugrel)
Používajte len pri REFRAKTÉRNEJ bolesti, po vyskúšaní nitrátov
Monitorujte dychovú frekvenciu - majte k dispozícii naloxón
Podávajte pomaly IV na minimalizáciu vedľajších účinkov

scenario_specific_response.patient_says: 'Bolesť je teraz oveľa lepšia... Cítim sa uvoľnene... trochu ospalo.' Pacient je viditeľne pohodlnejší, ale mierne sedovaný.
scenario_specific_response.clinical_effect: Významná analgézia a anxiolýza. Úľava od bolesti je vítaná, ale morfín oneskoruje absorpciu perorálnych antiagregačných liekov, ktoré pacient dostane v nemocnici. Podľa usmernení z roku 2025 už nie je prvou líniou. Rozumné použiť pri silnej refraktérnej bolesti po vyskúšaní nitrátov. Monitorujte útlm dýchania.
scenario_specific_response.teaching_point: Úloha morfínu pri AKS sa zmenila. STARÁ prax: rutinný morfín pre všetky AKS. NOVÁ prax (2025 ACC/AHA): morfín len pri REFRAKTÉRNEJ bolesti. Prečo? Morfín oneskoruje absorpciu perorálnych inhibítorov P2Y12 (tikagrelor, prasugrel), ktoré pacient dostane v nemocnici - oneskoruje antiagregačný účinok. Tiež: riziko nevoľnosti/vracania. Postup: Najprv vyskúšajte nitráty. Ak je bolesť stále silná po nitrátoch, POTOM je morfín rozumný. Podajte 2-4mg pomaly IV, možno opakovať. Monitorujte dychovú frekvenciu. Majte k dispozícii naloxón. Ale život zachraňuje aspirín + rýchla PCI, nie morfín.

normal_saline.indication: Udržiavanie IV prístupu, podávanie liekov, hypotenzia, dehydratácia

dosing.avoid_overload: NEPODÁVAJTE veľkoobjemové bolusy tekutín rutinne pri AKS

warnings: Pri AKS sa vyhnite agresívnym bolusom tekutín, pokiaľ pacient nerozvinie hypotenziu
Nadmerné tekutiny môžu zhoršiť pľúcny edém, ak sa rozvinie dysfunkcia ĽK
Zaveďte IV prístup včas, ale buďte konzervatívni s objemom tekutín

scenario_specific_response.clinical_effect: Udržiava IV prístup na podávanie liekov a pre prípad, že pacient rozvinie hypotenziu alebo zástavu. Vyhnite sa veľkoobjemovým bolusom tekutín - pacient je momentálne normotenzný (145/88) a nie je hypovolemický. Nadmerné tekutiny môžu zhoršiť pľúcny edém, ak sa rozvinie dysfunkcia ĽK z rozsiahleho IM. Zaveďte prístup, prepláchnite na udržanie priechodnosti, ale nepodávajte rutinné 500ml bolusy normotenznému pacientovi s AKS.
scenario_specific_response.teaching_point: IV prístup pri AKS slúži dvom účelom: (1) cesta pre lieky, ak je to potrebné, (2) objemová resuscitácia, ak sa rozvinie hypotenzia. Ale buďte konzervatívni s tekutinami. Na rozdiel od traumy, kde resuscitujeme tekutinami agresívne, pri AKS môžu nadmerné tekutiny ZHORŠIŤ výsledky spôsobením pľúcneho edému, ak je narušená funkcia ĽK. Zaveďte prístup, prepláchnite na udržanie priechodnosti, ale zadržte tekutiny, pokiaľ TK neklesne <90 systolický alebo pacient nejaví známky hypovolémie.

oxygen.mechanism: Zvyšuje obsah kyslíka v arteriálnej krvi
warnings: ERC 2021 a ACC/AHA 2025: NEPODÁVAJTE rutinne kyslík normoxickým pacientom s AKS
Podávajte kyslík LEN ak je SpO2 <90%
Hyperoxia (SpO2 >98%) môže zhoršiť výsledky AKS prostredníctvom vazokonstrikcie a voľných radikálov

scenario_specific_response.reason: SpO2 pacienta 96% = normoxický, kyslík NIE JE indikovaný podľa súčasných usmernení
scenario_specific_response.patient_says: Pacient prijíma kyslík, ale nevšimne si žiadny rozdiel.
scenario_specific_response.clinical_effect: ŽIADNY PRÍNOS a potenciálne poškodenie. Usmernenia ERC 2021 a ACC/AHA 2025 explicitne uvádzajú: NEPODÁVAJTE rutinne kyslík normoxickým pacientom s AKS. Dôkazy ukazujú, že hyperoxia spôsobuje koronárnu vazokonstrikciu a poškodenie voľnými radikálmi, čo môže zhoršiť veľkosť IM a výsledky. Toto je ZMENA PARADIGMY oproti starej praxi. Podávajte O2 len ak je SpO2 <90%.
scenario_specific_response.teaching_point: VÝZNAMNÁ ZMENA PARADIGMY: Kyslík už NIE JE rutinný pri AKS. STARÁ prax (pred 2015): každý s bolesťou na hrudníku dostane kyslík. NOVÁ prax (ERC 2021, ACC/AHA 2025): kyslík LEN ak je SpO2 <90%. Prečo? Štúdie ukázali, že rutinný kyslík u normoxických pacientov s IM môže zhoršiť výsledky - hyperoxia spôsobuje koronárnu vazokonstrikciu a poškodenie voľnými radikálmi. Tento pacient má SpO2 96% = nepodávajte kyslík. Ak SpO2 klesne <90%, POTOM podajte kyslík s cieľom 94-98%. Toto je medicína založená na dôkazoch, ktorá nahrádza tradíciu. Testuje, či študent pozná súčasné usmernenia vs zastaranú prax.

vital_changes.note: No immediate vital changes, antiplatelet effect at cellular level

anopyrin_aspirin.patient_says: Chews tablet, grimaces. 'Tastes awful... but if it helps...'
anopyrin_aspirin.clinical_effect: Antiplatelet effect begins within 14 minutes, prevents thrombus propagation

nitromin_nitroglycerin.patient_says: 'That helps a little. Less pressure. But my head hurts now.'
nitromin_nitroglycerin.clinical_effect: Symptomatic relief via preload reduction, headache expected

tramal_morphine.patient_says: 'Much better now... I feel relaxed... bit drowsy.'
tramal_morphine.clinical_effect: Significant analgesia and anxiolysis, mild sedation

oxygen.clinical_effect: Hyperoxia achieved but no benefit and potential harm per current evidence

3_minutes.patient_status: Pain intensifying, patient very distressed, 'Please do something!'
3_minutes.clinical_note: MI extending without treatment. Platelet aggregation continues at ruptured plaque site. Still salvageable but losing time. Every minute without aspirin increases thrombus burden.

6_minutes.patient_status: Severe distress, diaphoresis worsening, 'I can't breathe properly'
6_minutes.clinical_note: Possible early LV dysfunction developing. Anterior MI affecting large territory. Critical to give aspirin and get ECG NOW. Without intervention, patient progressing toward cardiogenic shock or malignant arrhythmia.

10_minutes.patient_status: Patient gasping, 'I think I'm dying... please help me...'
10_minutes.clinical_note: Extensive MI, developing cardiogenic shock. Still treatable but prognosis worsening. High risk of VF imminent. Myocardial damage progressing - need emergency PCI.

15_minutes.clinical_note: Cardiogenic shock and/or malignant arrhythmia imminent. Without emergency intervention, patient will arrest. Massive territory MI with pump failure or electrical instability.

critical_harm.name: tensiomin
critical_harm.primary_indication: Hypertension, tachycardia, AF, ACS (in stable patients)
critical_harm.why_dangerous: Beta blockers can cause bradycardia and hypotension in acute MI, especially with bradycardia or signs of heart failure. NOT first-line prehospital.

if_given.patient_response: CRITICAL: Patient's heart rate drops dangerously to 52/min. Blood pressure falls to 95/60. He looks pale and dizzy. 'I feel... faint...' Beta blocker causing dangerous hemodynamic compromise in acute MI.
if_given.clinical_note: Beta blockers are contraindicated in acute MI with bradycardia, hypotension, or heart failure. Can cause cardiogenic shock. NOT for prehospital use. Strictly hospital decision after hemodynamic stability confirmed.

critical_harm.teaching_point: Beta blockers have a role in ACS but NOT prehospital and NOT in acute phase if any signs of bradycardia, hypotension, or heart failure. In 1980s, beta blockers were given routinely early in MI - we learned this causes harm. Now: beta blockers started in hospital AFTER patient stabilized, AFTER excluding bradycardia/hypotension/heart failure. Prehospital: give aspirin, not beta blockers. Let cardiologist decide about beta blockers after PCI.

critical_harm.name: apaurin
critical_harm.why_dangerous: Respiratory depression, hypotension, masks clinical deterioration

if_given.patient_response: Patient becomes drowsy and sedated. 'I feel... sleepy...' His respiratory rate decreases. His anxiety is masked but underlying MI continues. Benzodiazepine obscures clinical status and can cause respiratory depression.
if_given.clinical_note: Benzodiazepines NOT indicated in ACS. They mask anxiety that actually indicates serious condition. Can cause respiratory depression and hypotension. Use verbal reassurance and definitive treatment (aspirin, PCI), not sedatives.

critical_harm.teaching_point: Patient's anxiety is APPROPRIATE - he's having a heart attack. His body is telling him something is seriously wrong. The answer is TREAT THE HEART ATTACK (aspirin, PCI), not sedate the anxiety. Benzodiazepines mask symptoms, cause respiratory depression, and delay recognition of deterioration. Use calm reassurance: 'We know what's wrong and we're taking you to get the treatment you need.' That's therapeutic, not diazepam.

critical_harm.name: cordarone
critical_harm.why_dangerous: Not indicated for sinus tachycardia, can cause bradycardia and hypotension

if_given.patient_response: No improvement in chest pain. Heart rate decreases but patient doesn't have arrhythmia - has appropriate sinus tachycardia from pain and sympathetic response.
if_given.clinical_note: Amiodarone for arrhythmias (VT, VF, AF with RVR), not sinus tachycardia. Patient's tachycardia is appropriate physiologic response to MI. Amiodarone can cause bradycardia and hypotension. Wrong indication.

critical_harm.teaching_point: Patient has sinus tachycardia (regular rhythm, rate 98-110), not arrhythmia. Tachycardia is APPROPRIATE - it's his body's response to chest pain and myocardial ischemia. Amiodarone is for dangerous arrhythmias (VT, VF, AF with rapid rate), not sinus tachycardia. Treating appropriate sinus tachycardia is wrong - it may mask deterioration. Treat the MI (aspirin, PCI), not the compensatory tachycardia.

critical_harm.name: novalgin
critical_harm.why_dangerous: Risk of anaphylaxis, hypotension, not appropriate analgesic for MI

vital_changes.note: Mild hypotension, risk of allergic reaction

if_given.patient_response: Patient's chest pain unchanged. Blood pressure drops slightly. Metamizole carries risk of anaphylaxis and agranulocytosis. Not appropriate analgesic for ACS.
if_given.clinical_note: Metamizole not indicated for ACS pain. Use nitrates and morphine per guidelines. Metamizole banned in many countries due to agranulocytosis risk. Use evidence-based ACS analgesics.

critical_harm.teaching_point: ACS pain management: nitrates (first-line for symptom relief), morphine (if refractory pain). Not NSAIDs, not metamizole, not paracetamol. Metamizole (dipyrone) banned in US, UK, and many countries due to agranulocytosis risk. Even where available, wrong choice for MI. Use guideline-directed therapy.

worsens.name: adrenalin
worsens.why_wrong: Increases myocardial oxygen demand, can worsen ischemia, provoke arrhythmias

if_given.patient_response: Patient's pain WORSENS. 'It's getting worse! My heart is pounding!' Heart rate and blood pressure spike. Epinephrine increases myocardial oxygen demand when patient already has supply-demand mismatch from MI. Can provoke VF.
if_given.clinical_note: Epinephrine contraindicated in conscious patient with ACS. Dramatically increases myocardial oxygen demand, worsens ischemia, provokes arrhythmias. Only use in cardiac arrest (VF/pulseless VT), not in conscious MI patient.

worsens.teaching_point: Epinephrine is for CARDIAC ARREST or ANAPHYLAXIS, NOT for conscious ACS patient. In MI, myocardium is ischemic - limited oxygen supply. Epinephrine massively increases myocardial oxygen DEMAND (↑HR, ↑BP, ↑contractility) while supply is restricted by occluded coronary. This worsens ischemia and can trigger VF. Save epinephrine for arrest. In conscious MI patient: aspirin, not adrenaline.

worsens.name: atropin
worsens.why_wrong: Causes tachycardia in patient who doesn't need it, increases myocardial oxygen demand

if_given.patient_response: Heart rate increases to 138. No benefit. Patient already has sinus rhythm with rate 98 - doesn't need atropine. Increased HR worsens myocardial oxygen demand.
if_given.clinical_note: Atropine for symptomatic bradycardia or high-degree AV block. Patient has normal sinus rhythm at 98/min - atropine not indicated. Causes unnecessary tachycardia which increases myocardial oxygen demand in MI.

worsens.teaching_point: Atropine for BRADYCARDIA (HR <50 with symptoms) or HIGH-DEGREE AV BLOCK. This patient has sinus rhythm at 98/min - normal rate for someone having MI. No indication for atropine. Giving it causes unnecessary tachycardia which INCREASES myocardial oxygen demand when patient's myocardium is already ischemic. Know your indications - not every cardiac drug is for every cardiac problem.

worsens.name: furosemid
worsens.primary_indication: Pulmonary edema, heart failure, volume overload
worsens.why_wrong: Can cause hypovolemia and hypotension in patient without volume overload

if_given.patient_response: Blood pressure drops. Patient becomes lightheaded. No benefit - patient doesn't have fluid overload. Furosemide causes unnecessary diuresis and hypotension.
if_given.clinical_note: Furosemide for PULMONARY EDEMA or VOLUME OVERLOAD. This patient has clear lungs, no crackles, no JVD, no peripheral edema - NOT volume overloaded. Giving diuretic can cause hypotension in normovole patient with MI. Wrong indication.

worsens.teaching_point: Furosemide is for PULMONARY EDEMA (crackles in lungs, pink frothy sputum) or HEART FAILURE (JVD, peripheral edema). Listen to lungs - this patient has CLEAR lung sounds bilaterally. No crackles. Not fluid overloaded. Giving diuretic risks hypotension. If patient develops pulmonary edema later (from LV dysfunction), THEN furosemide is appropriate. Current exam: no indication.

worsens.name: ca_gluconicum
worsens.primary_indication: Hypocalcemia, hyperkalemia, calcium channel blocker overdose
worsens.why_wrong: Not indicated in ACS, theoretical risk in digitalis toxicity

if_given.patient_response: No effect on chest pain or clinical status. Calcium not indicated.
if_given.clinical_note: Calcium gluconate for hypocalcemia, hyperkalemia (cardioprotection), or CCB overdose. Not indicated in routine ACS. Old theory about calcium in MI (since ischemia involves calcium) was disproven - doesn't help and may harm.

worsens.teaching_point: Calcium gluconate has specific indications: (1) Hypocalcemia (tetany, prolonged QT), (2) Hyperkalemia (peaked T waves, widened QRS - calcium protects heart), (3) Calcium channel blocker overdose. Not indicated in routine ACS. Don't give medications 'just in case' - treat actual problems with evidence-based interventions.

neutral.name: paracetamol
neutral.why_unnecessary: Inadequate for MI pain intensity, not indicated

if_given.patient_response: No effect on chest pain. Paracetamol inadequate for MI pain. Patient still in severe distress.

neutral.teaching_point: Paracetamol is for MILD pain (headache, fever). This is SEVERE crushing chest pain from myocardial ischemia. Magnitude mismatch. ACS pain management: nitrates (first), morphine (if refractory). Not paracetamol.

neutral.name: glucose

if_given.patient_response: No effect on chest pain. Patient confused why you're giving sugar.

neutral.teaching_point: Always check blood glucose in altered mental status. But this patient is alert, oriented, appropriate mental status. His problem is MI, not hypoglycemia. Focus on primary problem.

neutral.name: dormicum
neutral.why_unnecessary: Not indicated for conscious ACS patient

if_given.patient_response: Patient becomes drowsy. Anxiety masked but MI continues. Respiratory depression risk.

neutral.teaching_point: Same as apaurin - benzodiazepines mask appropriate anxiety, cause respiratory depression. Treat MI, don't sedate patient.

neutral.name: degan

if_given.patient_response: No effect on chest pain. Patient not nauseated.

neutral.teaching_point: If patient develops nausea from morphine, then antiemetic appropriate. But don't give prophylactically. Treat actual symptoms.

neutral.name: naloxone

if_given.patient_response: No effect - patient not opioid toxic.

neutral.teaching_point: Naloxone reverses opioids. Keep available in case of morphine overdose causing respiratory depression. But don't give prophylactically.

neutral.name: buscopan
neutral.why_unnecessary: For smooth muscle spasm, not cardiac pain

if_given.patient_response: No effect on chest pain. Wrong type of pain.

neutral.teaching_point: Buscopan for GI/GU smooth muscle spasm. This is cardiac ischemic pain from myocardial cells dying. Different pathophysiology, different treatment.

neutral.name: dithiaden
neutral.teaching_point: Antihistamine for allergic reactions. Not relevant to MI.

neutral.name: trombex
neutral.why_neutral: Appropriate medication but typically given in hospital with loading dose

if_given.patient_response: Appropriate antiplatelet but effect takes hours. Hospital will give loading dose.

neutral.teaching_point: Clopidogrel is part of dual antiplatelet therapy in ACS (aspirin + P2Y12 inhibitor). However, prehospital: give ASPIRIN definitely. Hospital will give loading dose of P2Y12 inhibitor (clopidogrel, ticagrelor, or prasugrel) based on patient's specific situation and whether going to cath. Focus prehospital: aspirin. Let hospital add second antiplatelet.

neutral.name: heparin
neutral.why_neutral: Appropriate medication but typically given in hospital

if_given.patient_response: Appropriate adjunctive therapy. Anticoagulation helps but hospital will manage this with loading dose.

neutral.teaching_point: Heparin is standard in ACS as part of antithrombotic therapy. However, prehospital priorities: (1) Aspirin, (2) 12-lead ECG, (3) STEMI network activation, (4) Rapid transport. Hospital will give heparin or other anticoagulant (enoxaparin, bivalirudin) based on bleeding risk and treatment strategy. Don't delay transport to give heparin prehospital. Time to PCI is more important.

neutral.name: ranisan

if_given.patient_response: No effect on chest pain. This is MI, not GERD.

neutral.teaching_point: CRITICAL: Don't assume chest pain is GERD without systematic assessment. This patient has CLASSIC MI presentation: crushing pain, radiation to arm/jaw, diaphoresis, duration >20 min, no relief with rest. Do 12-lead ECG FIRST before dismissing as GERD. Many MI patients die because someone said 'it's just indigestion.'

appropriate_advanced.name: ticagrelor
appropriate_advanced.why_good: Evidence-based second antiplatelet in ACS, superior to clopidogrel in trials
appropriate_advanced.requires: Loading dose 180mg PO (typically given in hospital after PCI decision made)

if_given.patient_response: Excellent advanced management. Ticagrelor loading dose appropriate in STEMI. Hospital will be pleased you started this. Antiplatelet effect develops over 2-4 hours.
if_given.clinical_note: Ticagrelor shows superiority to clopidogrel in PLATO trial for ACS. However, typically hospital decision based on PCI strategy and bleeding risk. Advanced prehospital treatment if given, but aspirin is the essential one. Bonus points for this advanced care.

appropriate_advanced.teaching_point: Ticagrelor (Brilique) is preferred P2Y12 inhibitor in ACS per ESC guidelines - superior to clopidogrel in PLATO trial (reduced CV death/MI/stroke). Loading dose 180mg. However: (1) Expensive, (2) Requires ongoing twice-daily dosing (compliance), (3) More bleeding than clopidogrel, (4) Hospital typically decides based on PCI strategy. Prehospital: aspirin is ESSENTIAL. Ticagrelor is bonus if you have it and protocol allows, but aspirin + rapid PCI are what save lives.

available_challenges.name: oxygen_in_normoxic_patient

trigger.condition: patient SpO2 is 96% (normoxic) and student hasn't checked SpO2 or mentions giving oxygen automatically

available_challenges.challenge_text: I see you're reaching for oxygen. Before we apply it, what's the patient's current SpO2 reading, and what do the 2021 ERC guidelines say about routine oxygen use in acute coronary syndrome?
available_challenges.teaching_goal: Evidence-based oxygen therapy - give ONLY if SpO2 <90%, not routinely. Tests knowledge of paradigm shift from traditional practice.
acceptable_responses: Student checks SpO2 and finds 96%
Student states current guidelines recommend oxygen only if SpO2 <90%
Student recognizes paradigm shift from old practice
Student cites ERC 2021 or ACC/AHA 2025 guidelines
Student understands hyperoxia may cause harm

resolution.if_good_reasoning: Excellent - you're applying evidence-based practice. The old 'everyone with chest pain gets oxygen' protocol has been replaced by selective use based on SpO2. His saturation is 96% - he doesn't need oxygen and giving it could actually cause coronary vasoconstriction. That's current best practice.
resolution.if_protocol_only: I hear you want to help the patient, and oxygen seems like it should help. But studies showed that routine oxygen in normoxic MI patients may actually WORSEN outcomes through coronary vasoconstriction and free radicals. Check his SpO2 - it's 96%. Per ERC 2021, oxygen only if <90%. What's your decision now?
resolution.if_struggling: Think about what oxygen does - it increases arterial oxygen content. But his SpO2 is 96% - his blood is already well-oxygenated. The problem isn't oxygen delivery, it's that his coronary artery is blocked. More oxygen in the blood won't fix the blockage, and studies show hyperoxia may cause coronary vasoconstriction. Save oxygen for when SpO2 drops <90%.

available_challenges.cognitive_goal: Prevent automatic protocol response without thinking. Challenge outdated practice with current evidence.

available_challenges.name: aspirin_dose_and_administration

trigger.condition: student orders aspirin but doesn't specify dose, route, or administration method

available_challenges.challenge_text: Good - aspirin is critical here. But I need specifics: what dose, what route, and most importantly, how should the patient take it?
available_challenges.teaching_goal: Specific dosing matters - 200mg loading dose, must be CHEWED for rapid effect. Tests attention to detail in critical medication.
acceptable_responses: 200mg PO chewed
Loading dose (not maintenance 100mg)
Must be chewed for faster absorption
Chewing achieves effect in 14 min vs 30 min swallowed
Even though patient takes aspirin at home, needs loading dose in ACS

resolution.if_good_reasoning: Perfect - 200mg chewed. You understand the pharmacokinetics: chewing achieves antiplatelet levels in 14 minutes versus 30 if swallowed. In ACS, every minute counts. Even though he takes 100mg at home, he needs a loading dose. The bitter taste is worth the mortality reduction.
resolution.if_protocol_only: Protocol says aspirin, yes. But the DETAILS matter: wrong dose (100mg maintenance vs 200mg loading) or wrong administration (swallowed vs chewed) can delay effect by 15+ minutes. In MI, that's significant time. What specific dose and how should he take it?
resolution.if_struggling: Think about goals: we need antiplatelet effect FAST. Regular daily aspirin is 100mg - takes 30 min to work when swallowed. In ACS: 200mg CHEWED achieves effect in 14 min. Yes, it tastes awful. But this is life-saving. Tell patient: 'Please chew this completely, I know it tastes bitter but it works faster.' Dose: 200mg. Route: PO chewed.

available_challenges.cognitive_goal: Precision in medication orders. Understanding pharmacokinetics informs clinical decisions.

available_challenges.name: ecg_before_network_activation

trigger.condition: student wants to activate STEMI network or call hospital but hasn't performed 12-lead ECG yet

available_challenges.challenge_text: Hold on - before we activate the STEMI network, what critical diagnostic test do we need to perform and document first? Why can't we activate without it?
available_challenges.teaching_goal: Cannot activate STEMI network without ECG confirmation. Tests understanding of system activation requirements.
acceptable_responses: Need 12-lead ECG first
Must confirm STEMI on ECG before activating network
Can't activate cath lab without ECG documentation
Slovak protocol requires ECG within 4 minutes
ECG needed to differentiate STEMI from NSTEMI

resolution.if_good_reasoning: Exactly right. We can't activate the STEMI network based on symptoms alone - we need ECG confirmation of STEMI. The cath lab team needs to know: (1) Is it STEMI? (2) Which territory? (3) Are there complications? The 12-lead answers these questions. Per Slovak protocol, get ECG within 4 minutes, then activate. Let's do the ECG now.
resolution.if_protocol_only: I appreciate your urgency - he clearly needs emergency care. But the system requires ECG confirmation. Why? Because STEMI activation mobilizes expensive resources (cath lab team called in), and we need diagnostic confirmation. Also, ECG tells us WHICH artery is occluded - helps cath team prepare. Do the ECG first, interpret it, THEN activate.
resolution.if_struggling: Think about it from the hospital's perspective: if you call and say 'STEMI activation,' they ask 'Where are the ST elevations? Which leads? Anterior or inferior?' You can't answer without ECG. Plus, symptoms can be misleading - GERD, pneumonia, anxiety can mimic MI. ECG is the objective test that confirms STEMI and guides treatment. Get it within 4 minutes per protocol.

available_challenges.cognitive_goal: Understand diagnostic confirmation requirements for system activation. Balance urgency with systematic approach.

available_challenges.name: nitrate_safety_checks

trigger.condition: student mentions giving nitrates but hasn't verbalized safety checks

available_challenges.challenge_text: Before giving nitroglycerin, walk me through the three critical safety checks you need to perform. What could go catastrophically wrong if you miss these checks?
available_challenges.teaching_goal: Nitrate safety: check BP, ask about Viagra/Cialis, identify MI location. Missing these can cause death.
acceptable_responses: Check blood pressure (hold if <90 systolic)
Ask about PDE5 inhibitors (Viagra, Cialis, Levitra)
Viagra contraindicated within 24h, Cialis within 48h
Identify MI location on ECG (inferior + RV = contraindicated)
Check for nitrate patches (remove before giving more)
Combination with Viagra/Cialis causes severe hypotension and death

resolution.if_good_reasoning: Perfect safety checks. (1) BP 145/88 - safe for nitrates. (2) Patient denies Viagra/Cialis in last 48h. (3) ECG shows anterior STEMI (V1-V4) - nitrates are SAFE in anterior MI. All three checks passed - you can give nitroglycerin safely. That systematic approach prevents deadly errors.
resolution.if_protocol_only: Nitrates are in the protocol for ACS, true. But they can KILL the patient if given wrong. Three scenarios where nitrates cause death: (1) BP <90 - profound hypotension. (2) Patient took Viagra/Cialis - combination causes refractory hypotension. (3) Inferior MI with RV involvement - nitrates drop preload and patient crashes. Check these three things EVERY TIME.
resolution.if_struggling: Think about deaths from medical errors: Patient having MI, paramedic gives nitrate, patient took Viagra for sex last night, patient's BP drops to 60 systolic, patient dies. This happens. Or: inferior MI + RV involvement, nitrate given, preload drops, cardiac output crashes, patient codes. Both preventable by asking three questions: (1) What's BP? (2) Any Viagra/Cialis in last 48h? (3) What does ECG show - anterior or inferior? This patient: BP 145 ✓, No Viagra ✓, Anterior STEMI ✓ = safe.

available_challenges.cognitive_goal: Systematic safety checks prevent lethal errors. Create mental checklist for high-risk medications.

available_challenges.name: time_critical_stemi_network

trigger.condition: STEMI confirmed on ECG but student hasn't activated network within 2 minutes of interpretation

available_challenges.challenge_text: You've confirmed STEMI on the ECG. What's your next immediate action, and why does it need to happen RIGHT NOW before anything else?
available_challenges.teaching_goal: STEMI network activation is time-critical - do it immediately after ECG interpretation, don't delay for full assessment or transport preparation.
acceptable_responses: Activate STEMI network immediately
Call KOS (dispatch) and PKI centrum
Transmit ECG to hospital
Pre-hospital cath lab activation saves 20-40 minutes
Every minute delay increases mortality
Don't wait for transport - activate NOW

resolution.if_good_reasoning: Exactly - STEMI network activation is THE priority once you've confirmed STEMI on ECG. Call dispatch, call PKI centrum, transmit ECG, state 'STEMI activation for 58-year-old male with anterior STEMI.' This triggers the cath lab team to come in early (they're not sitting there waiting). Pre-hospital activation reduces door-to-balloon time by 20-40 minutes and saves lives. Do it NOW, not in 5 minutes when you're done with exam.
resolution.if_protocol_only: I see you want to complete your assessment first - that's usually good systematic practice. But STEMI is the exception. The national protocol says: STEMI = EMERGENCY. Every 30-minute delay from diagnosis to PCI increases 1-year mortality by 7.5%. The cath lab team needs prep time. While you're doing complete exam and packaging patient, 10 minutes pass - that's myocardium dying. Sequence: Confirm STEMI → ACTIVATE IMMEDIATELY → then finish exam during transport.
resolution.if_struggling: Think about the big picture: patient's LAD artery is occluded RIGHT NOW. Myocardial cells are dying RIGHT NOW. PCI can open that artery, but cath lab team needs to be called in, room prepared, equipment ready - that takes time. If you activate NOW, they're ready when patient arrives. If you activate when you get to hospital, add 20-40 minutes. That's the difference between full recovery and permanent disability. Time is muscle. Activate now.

available_challenges.cognitive_goal: Understand system-level care. Front-load critical actions. Time-critical thinking.

usage_rules.selection_criteria: AI selects challenges based on actual student errors during scenario, prioritizing by priority level (critical > high > medium > low)
usage_rules.timing: Challenge immediately when trigger condition occurs, before allowing student to proceed
usage_rules.tone: Supportive and educational, never punitive. Frame as 'let's think through this together' or 'help me understand your reasoning'

available_evaluations.description: When to perform 12-lead ECG and activate STEMI network relative to other interventions
available_evaluations.evaluate_if: Student performed or didn't perform 12-lead ECG within first 5 minutes
optimal_sequence: Rapid initial assessment (30 seconds): crushing chest pain >20 min, radiation, diaphoresis = high-probability ACS
Immediate aspirin administration (2-3 minutes): 200mg PO chewed
12-lead ECG acquisition (within 4 minutes per Slovak protocol)
ECG interpretation (within 6 minutes): identify ST elevations V1-V4 = anterior STEMI
STEMI network activation (within 7 minutes): call KOS + PKI centrum, transmit ECG
Supportive care during preparation: check SpO2 (do NOT give O2 if ≥90%), IV access, consider nitrates if BP allows
factors_to_consider: Slovak national protocol: 12-lead ECG within 4 minutes mandatory
Time = muscle: every 30 min delay increases 1-year mortality 7.5%
Pre-hospital cath lab activation reduces door-to-balloon time by 20-40 minutes
Cannot activate STEMI network without ECG confirmation
Aspirin can be given before ECG (doesn't require diagnosis confirmation)
Target symptom onset to PCI <120 minutes
This patient: pain started 25 min ago, so ~55 min remains to achieve <120 min target

scoring.optimal: Recognized high-probability ACS within 1 minute, gave aspirin 200mg chewed within 3 minutes, performed 12-lead ECG within 4 minutes, correctly interpreted anterior STEMI (V1-V4 ST elevation), immediately activated STEMI network (called KOS and PKI centrum) within 7 minutes, transmitted ECG electronically if able, communicated estimated arrival time, appropriately withheld oxygen (SpO2 96%). Demonstrated understanding that early ECG and network activation are time-critical actions that directly impact survival.
scoring.acceptable: Performed ECG within 5-8 minutes, recognized STEMI, activated network within 10 minutes. Minor delays but all critical steps completed. Understood importance even if timing not perfect. Aspirin given early. May have given oxygen unnecessarily but recognized primary importance of ECG and activation.
scoring.suboptimal: Delayed ECG >10 minutes while performing complete assessment, OR performed ECG but delayed network activation, OR failed to communicate STEMI urgency to receiving hospital, OR gave oxygen to normoxic patient without checking SpO2. Completed steps but in wrong sequence or with significant delays that impact patient outcome.
scoring.dangerous: Did not perform 12-lead ECG at all, OR performed ECG but failed to recognize STEMI pattern, OR recognized STEMI but did not activate network (just said 'let's transport'), OR gave beta blocker causing bradycardia/hypotension, OR gave benzodiazepines masking clinical status. Critical system failures that result in major treatment delays and increased mortality risk.

available_evaluations.aar_teaching_point: STEMI is a SYSTEM emergency, not just a patient emergency. The entire healthcare system must activate to get patient from scene to cath lab rapidly. Your role: (1) Recognize ACS quickly (high-probability presentation), (2) Give aspirin immediately (doesn't require ECG - give on suspicion), (3) Perform 12-lead ECG within 4 minutes (Slovak standard, international guideline ≤10 min), (4) Activate STEMI network immediately upon diagnosis - don't wait until hospital arrival. Pre-hospital cath lab activation saves 20-40 minutes door-to-balloon time and reduces mortality. Every minute counts: 30-minute delay = 7.5% increase in 1-year mortality. The sequence is: Quick recognition (60 sec) → Aspirin (within 3 min) → ECG (within 4 min) → Interpret → Activate (within 7 min) → Transport. NOT: Complete assessment → ECG → Transport → Hospital activates cath lab (this adds 20-40 min delay). Front-load the system activation.

available_evaluations.description: Decision whether to give oxygen to normoxic ACS patient based on current evidence
available_evaluations.evaluate_if: Student gave or considered giving oxygen, OR appropriately withheld oxygen
optimal_sequence: Check SpO2: patient has 96% on room air
Recall current guidelines: ERC 2021 and ACC/AHA 2025 - oxygen ONLY if SpO2 <90%
Recognize patient is normoxic: SpO2 96% = no indication for oxygen
Withhold oxygen: can explain to patient if they ask ('your oxygen level is good, giving extra oxygen might actually be harmful')
Monitor SpO2 continuously: give oxygen if drops <90%
If patient deteriorates (cardiogenic shock, pulmonary edema), reassess oxygen need
factors_to_consider: Current evidence: routine oxygen in normoxic MI patients may worsen outcomes
Mechanism of harm: hyperoxia causes coronary vasoconstriction and free radical damage
SpO2 96% = normoxic, no physiological need for supplemental oxygen
Old practice ('everyone with chest pain gets oxygen') is OUTDATED (pre-2015)
ERC 2021 and ACC/AHA 2025 explicitly state: oxygen only if SpO2 <90%
This tests whether student knows current evidence vs outdated protocols
Appropriate to give oxygen if SpO2 drops <90% or patient develops pulmonary edema/cardiogenic shock

scoring.optimal: Checked SpO2 (96%), recognized patient is normoxic, correctly withheld oxygen based on current ERC 2021/ACC 2025 guidelines, demonstrated knowledge that routine oxygen in normoxic MI patients may cause harm through vasoconstriction and free radical damage, stated would give oxygen if SpO2 <90%, monitored SpO2 continuously. Articulated paradigm shift from old practice to evidence-based practice.
scoring.acceptable: Initially considered oxygen (old habit) but upon checking SpO2 or being prompted, correctly recognized patient is normoxic and withheld oxygen. Showed ability to update practice based on current evidence even if initial instinct was outdated. Checked SpO2 before committing to oxygen.
scoring.suboptimal: Gave oxygen to normoxic patient based on outdated 'chest pain = oxygen' protocol, didn't check SpO2 before applying oxygen, didn't know or cite current guidelines, but didn't cause obvious harm (SpO2 went to 99%, patient tolerates it). Applied old practice without thinking about rationale or checking current evidence.
scoring.dangerous: Applied oxygen and achieved hyperoxia (SpO2 >98%) without recognizing potential for harm, OR argued that 'more oxygen is always better' when questioned, OR gave oxygen instead of addressing critical priorities (aspirin, ECG), OR used oxygen as distraction from proper systematic assessment. Demonstrated outdated knowledge and resistance to evidence-based practice updates.

available_evaluations.aar_teaching_point: MAJOR PARADIGM SHIFT in ACS management: Oxygen is NO LONGER routine. OLD practice (taught until ~2015): 'Everyone with chest pain gets oxygen.' NEW practice (ERC 2021, ACC/AHA 2025): 'Oxygen ONLY if SpO2 <90%.' Why the change? Multiple studies (DETO2X-AMI, AVOID trial) showed routine oxygen in normoxic MI patients doesn't help and may WORSEN outcomes. Mechanism: hyperoxia (too much oxygen) causes: (1) coronary vasoconstriction (makes ischemia worse), (2) free radical formation (cellular damage), (3) reduced coronary blood flow. This patient has SpO2 96% = normoxic = well-oxygenated. His problem isn't oxygen delivery; it's that his LAD is occluded. Giving extra oxygen won't fix the blockage and may cause vasoconstriction. Correct approach: Check SpO2 first. If ≥90%, do NOT give oxygen. If <90%, give oxygen to target 94-98% (not >98%). Monitor continuously - if drops <90%, then oxygen indicated. This is evidence-based medicine overriding tradition. Student must know current guidelines, not what was taught 10 years ago.

available_evaluations.description: Recognizing need for loading dose aspirin (200mg chewed) rather than maintenance dose, even if patient takes daily aspirin
available_evaluations.evaluate_if: Student gave or attempted to give aspirin
optimal_sequence: Identify high-probability ACS (crushing pain, radiation, diaphoresis, >20 min)
Ask about aspirin use: 'Do you take aspirin at home?' Patient: 'Yes, 100mg daily, but I ran out 2 weeks ago'
Recognize need for LOADING dose in ACS: 200mg, not maintenance 100mg
Administer: 'Please chew this tablet completely, it tastes bitter but works faster'
Explain to patient: 'This is a higher dose than you usually take because of the heart attack - it works faster when chewed'
factors_to_consider: Loading dose 200mg achieves therapeutic effect in 14 minutes (chewed)
Maintenance dose 100mg takes 30+ minutes if swallowed
Even if patient takes daily aspirin, ACS requires LOADING dose for rapid effect
Patient stopped aspirin 2 weeks ago - antiplatelet effect completely gone
Chewing vs swallowing: 14 min vs 30 min to therapeutic levels
Aspirin reduces mortality in STEMI by 23% - most important prehospital drug
Give on high suspicion, don't wait for ECG confirmation

scoring.optimal: Asked about patient's aspirin use, recognized that daily aspirin at home (which patient hasn't taken for 2 weeks anyway) doesn't replace need for loading dose in ACS, administered 200mg PO chewed within 3 minutes, specified 'chewed' to patient for rapid absorption, documented dose and time, demonstrated understanding of pharmacokinetics (loading dose needed for rapid antiplatelet effect even if patient on maintenance therapy). Gave aspirin immediately on high suspicion of ACS, didn't wait for ECG.
scoring.acceptable: Gave aspirin 200mg within first 5 minutes, instructed patient to chew it, achieved appropriate administration even if didn't explicitly articulate difference between loading and maintenance dosing. Result was correct (200mg chewed early) even if reasoning not fully verbalized.
scoring.suboptimal: Gave aspirin 100mg (maintenance dose) instead of 200mg loading, OR gave 200mg but told patient to swallow instead of chew (losing 15 min in absorption time), OR significantly delayed aspirin administration (>10 min) while completing full assessment, OR didn't give aspirin at all initially but added it later when prompted. Achieved aspirin administration eventually but with delays or dosing errors that reduce efficacy.
scoring.dangerous: Did not give aspirin at all, OR gave aspirin but patient has known aspirin allergy (student didn't ask), OR gave aspirin after giving contraindicated medication like beta blocker first, OR said 'patient already takes aspirin at home so doesn't need more' (failing to understand loading vs maintenance), OR delayed aspirin >15 minutes for 'complete assessment.' Critical failure to provide the single most important prehospital intervention.

available_evaluations.aar_teaching_point: Aspirin is THE most important prehospital medication in STEMI - 23% reduction in mortality. Pharmacokinetics matter: In ACS, need LOADING dose 200mg (not maintenance 100mg) for rapid antiplatelet effect. Chewed aspirin achieves therapeutic levels in 14 minutes vs 30 minutes if swallowed - that 16-minute difference is significant in MI. Even if patient takes daily aspirin at home: (1) They may not have taken it today, (2) Maintenance dose is insufficient for acute thrombotic event, (3) Loading dose ensures rapid, complete platelet inhibition. In this case, patient stopped aspirin 2 weeks ago (ran out), so no residual antiplatelet effect. Sequence: Recognize probable ACS (60 sec) → Give aspirin 200mg chewed (within 3 min) → Continue with ECG and other interventions. Don't delay aspirin for 'complete assessment' - this is THE priority medication. Tell patient: 'Please chew this completely, I know it tastes awful but it works much faster.' The bitter taste is worth the life saved. Document: '200mg aspirin chewed at [time].' Timing matters: <3 min = optimal, 3-5 min = acceptable, >10 min = delayed (worse outcomes). Aspirin before anything except scene safety and high-probability ACS recognition.

usage_rules.selection_criteria: AAR Agent evaluates the 3 most relevant CDPs based on what student actually did during scenario. If student didn't give oxygen, evaluate CDP2 to see if they correctly withheld. If student didn't perform ECG, evaluate CDP1 for critical omission. If student gave aspirin, evaluate CDP3 for dose/technique.
usage_rules.scoring_method: For each CDP, assign performance level (optimal/acceptable/suboptimal/dangerous) based on observed actions, provide matched teaching point.
usage_rules.integration_with_performance: CDP evaluations assess quality of clinical reasoning and decision-making process, separate from but complementary to critical actions checklist. CDPs identify WHY student succeeded or failed, not just WHAT they did.

critical_actions_checklist.criteria: Identifies crushing chest pain >20 min, radiation to arm/jaw, diaphoresis, high-risk features
Chewed aspirin given within 3-4 minutes of arrival, correct dose (200mg loading, not 100mg maintenance)
12-lead ECG acquired within 4 minutes per Slovak protocol
Correctly identifies ST elevations in V1-V4, recognizes anterior STEMI, verbalizes diagnosis

critical_actions_checklist.action: Activate STEMI network (contact KOS and PKI centrum)
critical_actions_checklist.criteria: Calls dispatch and PKI center, transmits ECG if able, states 'STEMI activation' with patient details

critical_actions_checklist.action: Appropriate oxygen therapy decision (withhold if SpO2 ≥90% OR give if <90%)
critical_actions_checklist.criteria: Checks SpO2 first, follows ERC 2021 guidelines - does NOT give routine oxygen to normoxic patient

critical_actions_checklist.action: Administer Nitroglycerin 0.4mg SL (if BP allows and safety checks done)
critical_actions_checklist.criteria: Checks BP >90 systolic, asks about Viagra/Cialis use, verifies anterior MI (safe for nitrates), gives for symptom relief
IV established and flushed, ready for medications if needed

critical_actions_checklist.action: Initiate rapid transport to PKI centrum
critical_actions_checklist.criteria: Patient loaded and en route, team aware of time-critical transport, hospital pre-notified

common_errors.teaching_point: DO NOT give routine oxygen to normoxic ACS patients per ERC 2021 and ACC/AHA 2025 guidelines. Oxygen ONLY if SpO2 <90%. Hyperoxia may worsen outcomes through vasoconstriction and free radicals. This is major paradigm shift from old practice. Check SpO2 first, apply evidence-based guidelines.

Aspirin should be given within 2-3 minutes of arrival in suspected ACS. It's the most important prehospital drug for STEMI - reduces mortality by 23%. Give BEFORE completing full assessment. Give on high suspicion, don't wait for ECG confirmation. Time=muscle. Every minute of delay allows more thrombus formation.

common_errors.error: Delayed or didn't perform 12-lead ECG within 4 minutes
common_errors.teaching_point: 12-lead ECG must be acquired within 4 minutes per Slovak protocol (international guidelines ≤10 min). Cannot diagnose STEMI without ECG. Cannot activate STEMI network without STEMI diagnosis. Every minute of delay worsens outcomes. Sequence: Aspirin (3 min) → ECG (4 min) → Interpret → Activate. Don't delay ECG for complete head-to-toe exam.

common_errors.error: Failed to activate STEMI network or delayed activation
common_errors.teaching_point: STEMI network activation is MANDATORY in Slovak protocol and saves lives. Must call immediately after confirming STEMI on ECG - don't delay for complete assessment or transport preparation. Pre-hospital cath lab activation reduces door-to-balloon time by 20-40 minutes and reduces mortality. Call KOS, call PKI centrum, transmit ECG, state 'STEMI activation for [age]M with anterior STEMI.' Do it NOW within 7 minutes of arrival, not when you get to hospital.

common_errors.error: Gave nitrates without checking BP or asking about Viagra/Cialis
common_errors.teaching_point: ALWAYS check BP before nitrates (hold if systolic <90). ALWAYS ask about PDE5 inhibitors (sildenafil/Viagra, tadalafil/Cialis, vardenafil/Levitra) - combination with nitrates causes severe hypotension and death. Viagra contraindicated within 24 hours, Cialis within 48 hours, Levitra within 24 hours. Though anterior STEMI is generally safe for nitrates, BP and drug history are still critical. This is a medication safety fundamental - missing it can kill patient.

common_errors.error: Performed excessive assessment before critical treatments
common_errors.teaching_point: STEMI is time-critical emergency. Sequence should be: (1) Recognize high-probability ACS in first 60 seconds (crushing pain, radiation, diaphoresis, >20 min), (2) Give aspirin immediately (within 3 min), (3) Perform 12-lead ECG within 4 min, (4) Interpret STEMI, (5) Activate network within 7 min, (6) THEN complete detailed assessment during transport. Don't delay aspirin and ECG for full systematic head-to-toe exam - front-load the time-critical interventions.

common_errors.error: Didn't instruct patient to CHEW aspirin
common_errors.teaching_point: In ACS, patient must CHEW aspirin for faster absorption (onset 14 min vs 30 min if swallowed whole). This pharmacokinetic detail seems minor but makes clinical difference - 16 minutes faster antiplatelet effect. Tell patient: 'Please chew this tablet completely, I know it tastes terrible but it works much faster this way.' Document: '200mg aspirin CHEWED at [time].'

common_errors.error: Misinterpreted ECG or didn't recognize STEMI pattern
common_errors.teaching_point: Anterior STEMI shows ST elevation ≥2mm in two or more contiguous precordial leads (V1-V4). This patient: 3-4mm ST elevation in V1-V4. Reciprocal ST depression in inferior leads (II, III, aVF) confirms true STEMI (helps differentiate from pericarditis or early repolarization). Hyperacute T waves (tall peaked T waves) in anterior leads indicate very acute MI. Must master ECG interpretation - it's THE key diagnostic tool. ST elevation V1-V4 = LAD occlusion = anterior MI = large territory at risk = high mortality if not treated = EMERGENCY PCI.

common_errors.error: Gave wrong aspirin dose (100mg maintenance instead of 200mg loading)
common_errors.teaching_point: ACS requires LOADING dose 200mg for rapid, complete platelet inhibition. Maintenance dose 100mg (what patient takes daily at home) is insufficient for acute thrombotic event. Even if patient takes daily aspirin, give 200mg loading dose in ACS. Physiologic rationale: loading dose achieves therapeutic antiplatelet levels faster and more completely than maintenance dosing.

common_errors.error: Gave beta blocker (metoprolol) or other harmful medication
common_errors.teaching_point: Beta blockers can cause bradycardia and hypotension in acute MI. NOT for prehospital use in ACS. Beta blockers may be appropriate later in hospital AFTER patient stabilized, AFTER hemodynamics confirmed stable, AFTER excluding bradycardia/hypotension/heart failure. Prehospital: aspirin, nitrates (if safe), morphine (if needed). Let cardiologist decide about beta blockers after PCI. Other harmful meds: benzodiazepines (mask symptoms), adrenaline (increase O2 demand), atropine if not bradycardic.

cognitive_coach_questions.question: I notice you're giving oxygen. Can you tell me the patient's current SpO2 and what the current ERC 2021 guidelines say about routine oxygen use in acute coronary syndrome?
What is the single most important medication you can give this patient right now, and how quickly should it be administered? What's the evidence for mortality benefit?
What diagnostic test is absolutely critical within the first 4 minutes for this patient per Slovak protocol, and why is the timing so important for the system of care?

You've identified STEMI on the ECG. What is the next critical step according to Slovak national protocol, and why does it need to happen before transport? What are the time savings from pre-hospital activation?
Before giving nitroglycerin, what three critical safety checks must you perform or ask about? What could happen if you miss any of these checks?
I see you gave aspirin. What dose did you give, and can you explain the difference between a loading dose and a maintenance dose in acute coronary syndrome?
How should the patient take the aspirin - swallow it or chew it? What's the difference in time to antiplatelet effect, and why does that matter in STEMI?

key_concepts: Aspirin 200mg CHEWED is most important prehospital drug - 23% mortality reduction
12-lead ECG within 4 minutes mandatory per Slovak protocol - cannot activate STEMI network without it
Pre-hospital STEMI network activation saves 20-40 minutes door-to-balloon time - call immediately after ECG
DO NOT give routine oxygen if SpO2 ≥90% - ERC 2021/ACC 2025 paradigm shift
Nitrate safety checks: BP >90, no Viagra/Cialis in 24-48h, identify MI location (inferior+RV = contraindicated)
Time is muscle: every 30-minute delay diagnosis-to-PCI increases 1-year mortality 7.5%
Anterior STEMI (V1-V4) = LAD occlusion = large territory = high-risk
Front-load critical actions: Aspirin (3 min) → ECG (4 min) → Activate (7 min) → then complete assessment during transport
clinical_pearls: Crushing chest pain + radiation to arm/jaw + diaphoresis = classic MI triad
Reciprocal ST depression (inferior leads) confirms true STEMI vs pericarditis
Hyperacute T waves = very early MI (<1 hour from onset)
Chewed aspirin: 14 min to effect. Swallowed: 30 min. That 16-minute difference matters.
Loading dose aspirin 200mg even if patient takes daily 100mg - different goals
Patient anxiety in MI is APPROPRIATE - don't sedate it, treat the MI
Sinus tachycardia (HR 98-110) in MI is physiologic response - not an arrhythmia to treat
Beta blockers in acute MI can cause shock - strictly hospital decision after stabilization
Nitroglycerin headache is expected - cerebral vasodilation
Morphine delays absorption of oral antiplatelet drugs - use for refractory pain only
SpO2 96-100% is normoxic - do NOT give oxygen (may worsen via vasoconstriction)
STEMI activation mobilizes cath lab team - they're not sitting there waiting, need prep time
common_misconceptions: WRONG: 'Everyone with chest pain gets oxygen' - CORRECT: Oxygen only if SpO2 <90% per current evidence
WRONG: 'Patient takes aspirin at home so doesn't need more' - CORRECT: Always give 200mg loading dose in ACS
WRONG: 'Let me complete full assessment before treating' - CORRECT: Front-load critical actions (aspirin, ECG, activate) then assess during transport
WRONG: 'Swallowing aspirin is fine' - CORRECT: Must CHEW for faster effect (14 vs 30 min)
WRONG: 'I'll activate STEMI when we get to hospital' - CORRECT: Activate immediately after ECG confirmation (saves 20-40 min)
WRONG: 'Beta blockers good for MI' - CORRECT: Can cause shock in acute phase, hospital decision only
WRONG: 'Give nitrates to everyone with chest pain' - CORRECT: Check BP, ask about Viagra/Cialis, identify MI location first
WRONG: 'Morphine is first-line for MI pain' - CORRECT: Nitrates first, morphine only if refractory (morphine delays antiplatelet absorption)
WRONG: 'Patient's tachycardia needs treatment' - CORRECT: Sinus tach is appropriate response to MI, treat the MI not the compensatory tachycardia
WRONG: 'More oxygen is always better' - CORRECT: Hyperoxia causes coronary vasoconstriction and may worsen outcomes
evidence_based_updates: ERC 2021: Oxygen only if SpO2 <90% in ACS (DETO2X-AMI, AVOID trials)
ACC/AHA 2025: Routine oxygen NOT recommended in normoxic ACS patients
PLATO trial: Ticagrelor superior to clopidogrel in ACS (if available)
ISIS-2 trial: Aspirin reduces mortality 23% in MI (most important prehospital drug)
Time-to-treatment studies: Pre-hospital cath lab activation reduces door-to-balloon by 20-40 min
Morphine effects: Delays absorption of ticagrelor/prasugrel - use for refractory pain only
Beta blockers: Early IV beta blockers in acute MI increase shock risk - delayed oral therapy only after stabilization
